thinking.disposable_income: Roseland has relatively low income levels with median income of $49,808 and 50.1% households earning less than $50,000. This suggests residents are price-sensitive to transportation costs and sales tax increases.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With low per capita income ($24,754) and high percentage of low-income households, discretionary spending is limited. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact household budgets.
thinking.accessibility: 25.9% of households have no vehicle, and 20.1% use transit for work commutes. Good transit service is essential. 53.9% drive alone, so driving costs also matter significantly.
thinking.decision_rationale:
1. Prioritized lower transit fares ($0.75) to help transit-dependent residents
2. Favored lower sales tax (0.5-1.0%) due to limited discretionary income
3. Moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers
4. Balanced travel time improvements with cost burden
5. Considered high transit usage (20.1%) and no-vehicle households (25.9%)
